utterances: This is true.
Well, this is near the end of the revolt.
Its all the way in the southern part of Italy, in the toe of the boot, if you will, where its only about 35 miles wide.
It's very mountainous and there are very steep gorges there.
And Crassus and the Romans take advantage of this.
So in addition to these - using these gorges and the natural terrain, they build walls, and they closed off the whole peninsula, the whole 35 miles wide.
They're trying to keep Spartacus and his men from breaking out.
But they're fighting during the winter, and there are nights that are just too cold for the Romans.
And Spartacus and the slaves, being a very hardy bunch, they take advantage of this.
And on a cold and snowy night, they fill up a trench with branches and debris and corpses, and they go over these.
They use this as a way to get over this Roman trench, and theres point where they break through the wall and they affect an escape.
So they take advantage of a Roman lack of readiness.
Not just a great gladiator, a great general.
Spartacus...
Indeed.
...however, he was not totally in command.
There were others -factions, and they got defeated in detail eventually.
He was brought to terms himself by an army he could not defeat, and the terrible punishment then visited upon them by the Romans.
Spartacus, you say, died a soldier's death on the battlefield.
His body was never identified.
But all those captured were then crucified...
Yes.
...in a long row up the Appian Way between - all the way up to Rome and left there to rot, and many of them lingered for days.

The story of this conflict is told by Barry Strauss in his book, ""The Spartacus War,"" and told in rather less historical detail in the new television miniseries ""Blood and Sand,"" ""Spartacus: Blood and Sand.
Barry Strauss, thanks very much for being with us today.
Youre very welcome.
Thank you.
Barry Strauss joined us from Cornell University.
Youre listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Last week, Pakistani authorities arrested five young Muslim Americans from the Washington, D.C., area.
Investigators believe the young men left home in northern Virginia with the intention of getting training to go fight U.S.
forces in Afghanistan.
U.S.
officials say the group used social networking site Facebook and Internet videos on YouTube to contact extremist groups in Pakistan.
Small groups of self-radicalized American Muslims have plotted attacks in this country since 9/11, but there appears to be a change in this pattern lately.
The Alexandria Five, as they're being called, used contacts overseas.
So did Major Nadal Hasan, the man accused in the shootings at Fort Hood, and Najibullah Zazi allegedly planned to blow up buildings in New York after being trained in Pakistan.

NPR counterterrorism correspondent Dina Temple-Raston has been following this story and joins us in a moment with more about this case in particular and investigations into homegrown terrorists in general.
If you have questions about homegrown terrorists, how big a threat it might be and how to try to prevent it, give us a call, 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our Web site.
That's at npr.org.
Go there and click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Later in the program, David Dickerson with greeting cards for a holiday season in recession.
Emailers, if you've got ideas for seasonally and moodly correct cards, the address is talk@npr.org.
But first, Dina Temple-Raston joins us from New York.
Nice to have you back on the program.
Nice to be here.
And what do we know about these five young men?

Well, I'll tell you, what's really different about these five young men, they went overseas, and they clearly - FBI officials feel they clearly radicalized themselves watching videos on the Internet and seem allegedly to have wanted to find some sort of training so they could attack U.S.
troops overseas.

That's sort of the broad outline of it, but what is very interesting about this, for someone who watches a lot of these plots on a day-to-day basis, or a lot of these alleged plots, is that this group was very mixed.
I mean, generally you see groups of young men who have similar ethnicities.
And in this case, we've got someone from Eretria, we've got somebody from Egypt, we've got somebody from Pakistan.
And it's sort of this melting pot of Muslims who decided to come together, and decided what their common cause was, was to go overseas and potentially fight American troops.
So this is in distinction to the young Somalis from Minneapolis and St. Paul area who've gone over to fight in that country, a geographically coherent group.
This is - the geographic coherence seems to be northern Virginia.
Yes, exactly, and the fact that they all speak English with an American accent.

And so these are - we've all thought, all along, again unlike the Somalis who are a distinct community and recent arrivals, that American Muslims are much better assimilated in this country than they are in places like Britain and that the appeal of homegrown terrorism may be diminished because of that.
Yes, I think that's been a false hope for some time.
There were mostly two groups that intelligence officials were taking a look at in this country as being less well-assimilated than other groups.
And that would be Somalis - and as you say, the Somalis in Minneapolis, that's where the largest concentration of Somalis in this country are - and then the second group was Yemenis.
And what they have in common is that they tend not to assimilate as well because they're working three jobs.
They're usually pretty poor.
Usually, their households are headed by mothers who came over here alone.
They are very connected to the political goings-on in their home countries, and they never really get politically connected to what's going on in this country.
And together, that makes - puts them in a kind of bubble that intelligence officials think make them much more susceptible to radicalization.
For all their mutual suspicions, the Sunni and Shiite community leaders turn up at the appointed hour at Peterson's combat outpost.
Like anywhere that has power in Baghdad, the low rumble of a generator is a constant backdrop.
At first, each talks about how he was abused by the other side.
Captain Peterson interrupts.
Speaking through an interpreter, he says the point is to move forward.
The purpose for the day is to actually make your community better, and we're looking for ways to do that.
Despite the inauspicious beginning and a certain amount of posturing, these men got down to business quickly, surprisingly quickly.

They agreed they should choose one small area - maybe just a couple of streets - to show that with Peterson's protection, people can return to their homes and that Shiites and Sunnis can live together again.
Abu Assama is a Sunni.
(Through translator) Let us start with a square block and make it a model for the rest of the blocks.
We, the three to four good men, cannot clean up a neighborhood.
It is impossible.
But we can start with a square block.
This means that refuges from other areas who moved in to abandoned houses here will have to move again to make room for those returning.
It means new checkpoints.
It's a lot to ask.
Abu Nasser(ph), a respected Shiite, supports the proposal.
(Through translator) We are not the only people who have suffered.
All of Iraq has suffered, but we hoped to be a model for others.
Peterson brings in a map and the leaders eventually agree on an area emptied of both Sunnis and Shiites.
Peterson urges them on, telling them how honored he is they have met.
An Iraqi army major sitting in on the meeting shakes his head.
I think they will - can't make a deal.
They can't.
Major Jasseb(ph) says these are good men, but he says they don't represent the street or the terrorists who still threaten the neighborhood.
He says extremists from both sides will pick them off.
It is still too soon.
Maybe before one, two years, maybe we can.
And now, we can't.
But even though these men know the risks, the local leaders keep on with their talks.
They agree to weekly meetings.
It's a first step.
Anne Garrels, NPR News, Baghdad.
NPR's Nina Totenberg reports.
That's the way Wisconsin Right to Life financed ads like this one in 2004, when Senator Russell Feingold was on the ballot.
(SOUNDBITE OF CAMPAIGN AD)
This group of U.S.
senators is filibustering, blocking qualified nominees from a simple yes or no vote.
Contact Senators Feingold and Cole and tell them to oppose the filibuster.
Visit befair.org.
Justice Scalia, who dissented in 2003 piped up.
Maybe we were wrong last time.
You thought so then, replied Clement, but this is still the typical sham-issue ad covered by the law's restrictions.
How do you know the motive of this ad was to defeat Feingold?
Maybe it was to change his mind.
Answer: Feingold had voted 20 or 22 times for the filibuster.
This was not going to change his mind.
Justice Scalia - his voice rising: This is the First Amendment, we don't make people guess whether their speech is going to be allowed by Big Brother or not.
It seems your position is inconsistent with our decision holding that there can be a challenge to the way the law is applied.
If this isn't a legitimate challenge, then give me an example of one that would be.
Answer: An ad funded by an organization like the ACLU that cannot setup a political action committee under the law and thus cannot raise money to fund campaign ads.
In contrast, Wisconsin Right to Life could have done that.
Next up was lawyer James Bopp, representing Wisconsin Right to Life.
He quickly faced questions from Justice Breyer who noted that the ad says contact Senator Feingold but provides no phone number.
It says go to a Web site and if you go there, what you see is, defeat him, defeat him, defeat him.

If it is true as we said four years ago that TV ads are the single best way to get someone defeated or elected and then you allow corporations and rich-givers to pay for these ads, then goodbye McCain- Feingold.
